newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan money supply recovery intact - economists.
newsitem.headline: Japan money supply recovery intact - economists.

text.p: Japan's broadly defined money supply average of M2 plus certificates of deposit (M2+CDs) in November showed that money supply was continuing a gradual recovery, albeit at a slow pace, economists said on Wednesday.
M2+CDs grew a preliminary 3.3 percent year-on-year in November, compared with growth of 3.7 percent in October, the Bank of Japan said on Wednesday.

"The growth rate of M2+CDs fell 0.4 percentage point in November, but a 2.0 percent month-on-month rise in the seasonally adjusted, annualised figure showed that a gradual recovery was intact," said Mamoru Yamaguchi, an economist at Nikko Research Centre.
Yamaguchi also said that money supply was boosted in November 1995 because investors had shifted a portion of their maturing funds to commercial bank deposits.
"If the impact of such a one-time factor is excluded, one could say money supply maintained roughly the same pace of growth in November as in recent months," he said.
Satoru Kado, a senior economist at Sanwa Research Institute, said weak bank lendings were holding money supply growth down.
"Slow bank lendings are capping money supply growth. Large corporations are preferring to raise funds through corporate bond issues than bank loans," he said.
